title: Russian I
requirements: Not for students who have taken RUSS2000,2001,2050,3000 or 3050
description: As the first in a series of six language courses, this course invites students without prior knowledge of Russian to explore the basic features of the Russian language. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written Russian through interactive class work, homework and online exercises. They will become familiar with the basic concepts of Russian grammar and learn how to interact in some simple everyday situations.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to:  • Understand short, simple messages and announcements;  • read short simple texts and find specific information;  • communicate in simple, routine situations;  • write simple notes, messages and short personal letters.  By the end of the course, students should be able to perform at Level A1.1 of the Common European Framework
syllabus: RUSS1000      Unit Topics Content & Structures   1 Russia and Russian. Introduction to the Russian language and culture.  Alphabet. Consonants and vocals. Intonation.    2  Popular occupations. Self-introduction.  Personal pronouns. Nouns’ gender (introduction). Here and there. Unstressed (o).   3 My family. Who/ what is it?  Possessive pronouns (introduction). Negation. Numerals 1 to 10. Consonants (hard and soft).   4  Strange city. Asking and giving directions.  Gender of nouns. Where is?   5 Well-known personalities. Who? Where? When? Possessive pronouns. Plural of nouns (introduction). Whose? (introduction) To know.   6 Living. My room.    Plural of nouns. Whose? Cases system of nouns (introduction).   7 In the shop. I like it. How much? Numerals 11-100. Adjectives. Which? Days of the week. Verb conjugation I and II.

title: Russian II
requirements:
Pre-requisite: RUSS1000
Not for students who have taken RUSS2001,2050,3000 or 3050
description: Building on the knowledge acquired in RUSS1000, this course aims to further develop students' ability to communicate in Russian in various everyday situations. It also seeks to give students a taste of Russian culture and invites them to explore cultural differences. Through intensive practice students will develop more confidence in interacting in Russian while further expanding and solidifying their understanding of the basic grammar and pronunciation patterns.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will have acquired the ability to:  • read Russian texts containing high frequency lexis and basic structures;  • understand basic conversations or understand the gist of more complex conversations dealing with familiar topics;  • talk on familiar and simple topics with reasonable fluency;  • ask for information, make suggestions and make requests fairly confidently;  • write a short personal text or letter about familiar subjects.  By the end of the course, students should be able to perform at Level A1.2 of the Common European Framework.
syllabus: RUSS2000      Unit Topics Content & Structures   Revision 1-7 Self-introduction. My family. Popular occupations.  Alphabet; numbers; Whose? Possessive pronouns; gender of nouns.    8 In the supermarket. How much? Verb conjugation I,II. Cases system of nouns. Prepositional case (Where, Где? (в, на)). Accusative case (Whom? Кому? / What? Что?).    9            Leisure time. Accusative case (Where? Куда? (в, на)). Days of week. The verb “to go” (ходить, идти, ездить, ехать).    10 Transportation. Seasons.  In the shop. I like it!     Past tense. The verb “to go” (ходить, идти, ездить, ехать) in the past. When? Time; modal verbs: I can; I want. Adjectives. Colors.    11 Eating & drinking.  What time is it now? Perfective and imperfective verbs. Time. Dative case (To whom? К кому?) Genitive case.

title: Russian III
requirements:
1.Not for students who have taken RUSS3000 or 3050
2.Pre-requisite: RUSS2000 or 2050
description: This course aims to further enhance students’ communication skills in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Students are expected to communicate confidently in a wider range of social interactions including more formal situations and simple professional contexts as well as reporting past events and sharing experience. At the end of this course, students will have completed a proficiency level comparable to level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to:•    talk about daily situations related to shopping, ordering and paying in a restaurant, health issues.•    use essential linguistic features of Russian such as plural forms of neuter and masculine nouns, accusative case for objects, instrumental case of nouns, the past tense and the future tense of verbs.
syllabus: Lesson Speech Acts Grammar Culture   Unit 6.1, 6.2  Describing your house. Explaining location of objects.   Imperative form of verbs. Construction “I have + event”. Plural nouns. Days of week. Calling for home   repair services.   Unit 6.3 Talking about your free time and ways to rest at home. Verbs describing activities at home. The accusative case for objects.   Popular hobbies in Russia.   Unit 7 Talking about food and recipes. Ordering and paying in a restaurant. The instrumental case in a construction “with something”. The future tense of verbs. Inviting friends for dinner.   Unit 8.1, 8.2 Talking about health and lifestyle. Giving recommendations. Personal pronouns with age. Construction “I had”. Visiting a doctor

title: Russian IV
requirements:
1.Not for students who have taken RUSS3050
2.Pre-requisite: RUSS2001
description: This course aims at increasing students’ communicative fluency in oral and written Russian. Using a variety of classroom activities and multimedia, students will build up their competence in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Through intensive practice they will be able to communicate in a wide range of social situations with the appropriate awareness of the pragmatic rules involved. Students will receive guidance in the process of composing longer texts displaying a range of registers and styles relating to past, present and future events.
